column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0093] Alternatively, the double-sided polycrystalline compacts of the present invention can be attached to an additional substrate 40, as shown in FIG. 10A.
#Text=FIG. 10A illustrates a drill bit having two polycrystalline layers 14 and 16.
#Text=FIG. 10B illustrates a drill bit produced by conventional methods having a single polycrystalline layer 42.
#Text=The substrate layers 12 and 40 shown in FIG. 10A can be formed simultaneously with the polycrystalline layers 14 and 16.
#Text=For example, a cup assembly can be formed by placing layers of superabrasive and substrate materials as either solid or powder to form a precursor assembly.
#Text=The assembly can then be subjected to HPHT conditions.
#Text=Alternatively, each layer can be formed in separate steps and the substrate 40 can be attached as discussed above.

#Text=[0094] Extending the effective thickness of the polycrystalline layers in accordance with the principles of the present invention allows production of polycrystalline tools having a thickness or effective thickness greater than about 1.6 mm to about 2 mm, without regard to superabrasive particle size.
#Text=An additional benefit of the polycrystalline compacts and inserts of the present invention includes extended tool life.
#Text=Specifically, traditional PCD and PCBN inserts are single sided and can be attached to a tool body.
#Text=Upon wear of the polycrystalline surface the insert is typically removed and replaced.
#Text=The polycrystalline compacts and inserts of the present invention include at least two abrading or cutting surfaces, thus at least doubling the useful life the tool.

#Text=Further, having polycrystalline superabrasive on two opposing edges of the compact or insert allows for applications such as reversible cutting and abrading, and other applications made possible by having a double-sided PCD/PCBN which are difficult or not possible using traditional single sided compacts.

#Text=[0095] The polycrystalline layers of the present invention can be joined to one another or to a substrate using a HPHT welding process in order to manufacture the various embodiments of the present invention.
#Text=The HPHT welding process is a method, in accordance with one aspect of the present invention, of joining two surfaces, at least one of which can be a polycrystalline layer.
#Text=As an illustration of this process, a polycrystalline layer and a substrate can be joined as described below.
#Text=A substrate can be provided having a contact surface.
#Text=The substrate can be formed as described above in connection with other embodiments of the present invention.
#Text=The contact surface can be any surface, or portion of a surface, of the substrate which is configured to be joined to a polycrystalline layer.
#Text=Generally, this contact surface is a flat surface, however contoured and shaped surfaces can also be suitable for use in the HPHT welding process of the present invention.
#Text=At least one polycrystalline layer can also be provided having a surface configured for joining to the contact surface.
#Text=The polycrystalline layer can be a solid PCD or PCBN or can be a layered polycrystalline article such as a double-sided compact, described previously, or a sandwich segment, described below.
#Text=These polycrystalline layers are preferably HPHT sintered products produced in a prior separate step.
#Text=[0096] One or both of the polycrystalline surfaces and the substrate contact surfaces can be coated with a coupling agent.
#Text=The coupling agent can be any material capable of acting as a sintering aid under HPHT conditions.

#Text=Suitable coupling agents can include, without limitation, cobalt, titanium, nickel, manganese, iron, silicon, aluminum, vanadium, chromium, zirconium, molybdenum, tungsten, tantalum, and alloys thereof.
#Text=Currently preferred coupling agents include cobalt and titanium.
#Text=Titanium and several other coupling agents such as tantalum, aluminum, zirconium, silicon, and alloys of these metals can act as both carbide and nitride formers.
#Text=Coating of the coupling agent can be performed by a wide variety of processes.
#Text=Several suitable coating processes include, but are not limited to, sputtering, electrodeposition, electroless deposition, spot-welding, and combinations thereof.
#Text=In one embodiment, coating of the coupling agent can be performed by sputtering.
#Text=The coating can be applied at various thicknesses depending on the final tool desired.
#Text=However, the coating typically can have a thickness of from about 1 .mu.m to about 0.5 mm, and preferably from about 3 .mu.m to about 20 .mu.m.

#Text=One consideration in determining an appropriate thickness for the coating layer is that a thinner layer can result in a more uniform boundary in the final tool from one joined layer to an adjacent layer.
#Text=Further, extremely thick layers may result in a multi-layer polycrystalline article having excess coupling agent.
#Text=The presence of excess coupling agent or excessive amounts of metal binder can weaken the final article at high operating temperatures.

#Text=[0097] After the coating is formed on either or both of the surfaces to be joined, the surfaces can be placed in contact with one another in a predetermined orientation to form a polycrystalline precursor.
#Text=The polycrystalline precursor can then be placed in a HPHT apparatus and subjected to high pressure and high temperature sufficient to bond surfaces having a coupling agent coated therebetween.
#Text=During this HPHT welding process the coupling agent acts to sinter adjacent layers together.
#Text=As mentioned in connection with previous discussions of HPHT processes, typical temperatures can range from about 1,200.degree.
#Text=C. to about 1,500.degree.
#Text=C. and pressures can range from about 1 GPa to about 7 GPa, although conditions outside these ranges can be used.
